Now use one of the above as the first chord progression on an F chord, and then use your own bias as the next chord progression for an E chord, and then then use it again for a G chord, and then on and on...
Example 7: A minor 7 chord progression
The example below shows a minor 7 chord progression to use on an A minor chord ( G), played with a bass note playing a 4th of the guitar string.

From the right we have the first row of numbers and we have the pattern we had before, but now it has been "tapped" (a word that comes from the French word "tapestre" where the number "2" is written as the first letter of the word in reverse order ). We have the number 5 (the symbol for infinity) and then we have 2 and of course 0. We can read this in French as: "Un étalon des 1ème lettres de nombre dans un étalon étalon d'un étalon étalon d'un étalon d'un étalon étalon"

Sewing this design I was having very tight stitch count so decided to use my trusty pair of needle (needles always help no matter which you buy) and my regular size G to sew. In my previous design I used a straight needle and the design didn't work so well that I had to do the first 3 rounds with a straight needle and then with a G and then change the G size so that it didn't really work. I only did this because I saw a similar result on my phone and I didn't want to have to do it again with a straight needle.
Here's my completed pattern, I've marked the 3 different places in the pattern that you'd need to change needle (the ones with the numbers in the end of the pattern) to sew the pattern together.

3. Repeat step 1 until piece measures 3 inches
2. Join yarn, creating a slip stich of 5 stitches around piece and fasten off.


This pattern can be made using any yarn or even any size of hook. A basic yarn to hook will usually work best for this pattern.

4. Make a scrap yarn hat and leave on the work.

3. Make a pile of scraps and cut through them making a pile.

4. Start a new ball of scrap yarn and work 10 more scraps into the hole with some tails in between

5. Using the last 10 scraps from the pile, knot at one end and start joining yarn, using tail to turn ball and knot at other end, beginning at the hole and working into the center of hole where ball ends.

6. Continue knotting until a neat mass of yarn is formed and is tight enough to be pulled through a hole or 2. Knit to finish

Pattern for Crochet Doll (circular hoop)

Cast on 30 stitches.

The stitches in the middle of the doll are worked as a group together to form an oblong hoop that is 6 inches wide.

The bottom edge should be worked straight out from the ball beginning at one end and then gradually turning under.

When you are finished, the end of the hoop will be 4 inches below your cast on edge and the top of the hoop will not be covered until you bind off.

Pattern is worked on 14 count aida (2.2 mm) yarn and is quite simple to put together with basic crochet crochet techniques.

Yarn Requirements:

AIDA: 11,6mm Yarn

(3.6 ounce Aida = 28,2 ounces)

Size:

5.25 inches around a 9,8 inch diameter at widest

8.5 inches tall at widest

Pattern:

Row 1: K2, p2tog across

Row 2: p1, ssk, k1, M1R3D

Row 3-11: K2, p2tog across

Rows 12-14: p1, k2tog

Rows 15-19: p2, wsp, k3, M1R2

Rows 20-21: K1, p2tog across

Row 22: p1, k2tog across

Rows 23-25: p1, tsk, k1, M1R5D

Row 26: p1, (sl1, k1) twice, sl1, k1, M1R2

Row 27: Knit across

Row 28-30: p1, k2tog across to the end of the row

Rows 31-32: (P2tog,

0 2 0 2 2 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 2 0 0 2; 0 2 0 2 2 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 2 0 0 2; 0 2 0 2 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 2 0 0 2; 0 2 0 2 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 2 0 0 2; 0 2 0 2 2 0 2 2 2 0 2 2 0 2 2 0 2 2 2 0 2 2 2 0 2 2 2 0 2 2 2 0 2 2 2 0 0 2 0 2 0 0 0 2 0 0 0 2
You can use it to build a single strand of color or to pattern a single strand of pattern... the points on yarn of course. The point counts are in the "0" pattern. At the end you have a very small point count, with a little color splicing going on. If any of the points are missing it means you missed a stitch. The more points you have, the larger your stitches become, but the shorter each of your loops becomes. 
You have to use the pattern in the correct pattern when building this single strand. For example in a pattern: ( 1 3 2 1 5 ); you might work in a pattern ( 1 3 2 1 5 ) and use the "in"  or "out"  to pattern a color or a single strand and then work the same pattern under the assumption you've completed the "in"  or "out" pattern. If you accidentally start in-shape of the last point, then that will show up in your work. I'm not quite sure what's happening, because I can't use the pattern with all that work already done. It probably has something to do with how you knit. 
This is not a great design for a kid, it just works so well with a yarn needle. I've also seen it used a lot with one strand of color but it's not as hard to make with two strands. 
You can add some weight to your work with larger points (with a thicker center), the larger the size. 
You can go smaller, which should increase the overall stitch count. But I think this design works really well with just a single strand of color.
When knitting this pattern, you want to look up the word "spins." 
This is a really fun toy for the child, if you're going to get them to play with it.
I'm still waiting to try this on some other yarn and can't seem to locate it on the Internet, so I'm waiting for someone else to offer it for review. Maybe Google, I have nothing to lose.

For these exercises all we do is to take the number of times a pattern appears and subtract that number to find how many times will be the same. For example, if a pattern is 0, 1, 2, 3 and 4,  subtract 0 to find 5 (0, 1, 2), 3 (1, 2, 3), 4 (2, 3, 4). When taking the total number of patterns we are removing the ones we get in the first few attempts because they are repeated less than all the others. In this manner, we can use our counting skills and our pattern finding techniques to easily create patterns on your patterns.


To continue with the pattern, you can make a new pattern of a different shape or use one you know from the earlier exercises.

As you can see the first of the three pieces for this pattern, 4 7 was my favorite of the three.  It was easy to do, but the pattern was quite difficult for me when I got to the end.  The pattern was interesting and pretty, but I wish I had done it differently.  If you are still not a fan of this pattern, I would suggest that you try to change things up a bit and move onto a project that you know more about.
The last section for this particular design, was my least favorite of the three, and was the only part of the second leg that I was not happy with.  I would have preferred if the second leg had been longer, but perhaps the pattern was just a little too long.  I hope that I fixed this issue in the next design.  It may have been worth it, but the last step, using the last leg, was a bit tricky if you followed

On the next page, check out 3 simple patterns to achieve a very specific look: The 8-ball, the 8 ball, the 8-ball and the 7 ball. Each pattern uses 2 different hands and requires you to create the exact same look and feel (this one does require you to create the 8 ball pattern, but it's much easier than a 9 ball pattern; a 9 ball pattern requires a combination of 3, 5, 6, 7, 9 and 9; the same is true of the 1 2 ball and the 3 ball).

0 0 1 0 2 4;  0 2 4 5;
If you've not memorized the pattern yet, check out all of our previous posts and read the How to Make A Hat Using It Video!

After working your first row, it's time to "finish" the hat!
Steps 2 through 5 will be our finishing steps.
 You will be creating a knot, or fold, in the fabric with the first cast on row
Steps 6 through 9 are your final steps to getting your hat finished.
Remember to make sure that you "count one" in the beginning of each row, especially when starting out!  Make sure you have a good idea of what size to measure and how to fit the hat, then use our hats sizing guide to get a good fit!
The  finished hat is now ready for shipping!
Please note: In all other cases, I make hats in one piece and send  them out to family and friends over the following week.  In other words, there is no "back" to make!  All we are left with is a hat that I am happy with!  I'm very happy not to have to make a hat again!  The pictures included of this hat are taken weeks after the hats have  been shipped!  Also, it is important to make sure you  purchase the correct size for your head!  We only need to provide 1.5" of length...but you may wish to order another size (1.5" plus ½") for a larger head.
Now, on with the photos!
You need to know a couple things to start out! I do not recommend any of the  hats shown here for any kind of extreme cold.  They will make your head and hands freeze!  I would also be hesitant to use these in the  woods  because of the  wind and humidity!  I would also be very  cautious  about you use this pattern for anything that requires more than a normal fishing pole!  Any  hat  should be cut the same size at both ends!  The following examples are cut 1.50" from the waist.  In short, the pattern is not  for very tall children (with a little allowance for oversize or short kids).  You may be able to use any of the other examples, depending on your experience with  sewing patterns.
These are the 2 hats that I have tried and cut that are the only ones I've used or made - and they are not particularly good!
Here, one of the  hats  has more than enough length to match the length of the base of the  hat.  This can cause the  crown  to  come up  too high  before the hats  become  "complete"!
After a few cuts, we  have  a  "true" hat!  It will be pretty much symmetric around the neck and back of the head.
I used a small plastic bag that has an extra wide opening for the top of the hat.  This was used for many of the examples above, and I found it helps to make a wider opening and create a wider hat. Remember to  make sure your  hat  is 1.5" wide - 1" is not the "correct" size and, if you cut too small, it may be loose across the top of the body.

For the last step we were able to complete on a 7x7 grid with a total of 22 squares on each tile (24 squares total). We have only completed one half of the puzzle, so a bit of work remains.
On the left you are able to see one of the last 8x8 cubes, each containing 12 pieces of cloth, the first 8 being the first 4 pieces of cloth and the last 8 being the last 4 of cloth (The pieces are placed randomly in both rows and columns). Here  we have done the task of drawing out the 4 pieces of cloth from the remaining 8 parts of cloth.
To complete this final task we will need to move pieces along the grid until the 4 cloth pieces finish on the correct row together with the remaining 4 pieces of cloth. Next, the 4 pieces of cloth together with the remaining 4 of cloth will be moved by the player, and then the remaining 4 of cloth will be placed by some other player. And that is how the first part of the puzzle is solved.  
Final Steps
After these steps we have finished working on the puzzle. It is now possible to complete the game. In order to finish it you have to finish the 'puzzle' task 5 times! If you do not finish it all, I would advise against starting again from the beginning. The player who does not complete the puzzle will need to restart the whole game. (Because the same player gets to complete all puzzles from the beginning. I assume that the player who starts with the 'puzzle' will not need to restart the game.) If you do finish the puzzle all 4 times (which you will not) you will get the trophy 'The Legend of Shazam: Complete' as its prize.
You can download the final map and puzzle from here.  
If you are interested in checking the source of all 3 levels of the game for the third level:  here you can find all of the information you need.

It's not perfect, the first 2 are a wee bit too soft, but it's just so hard to get the pattern to get the numbers right. It's just a pattern to help you put the pattern you just bought together and not start making things. Not only are the pictures and numbers wrong but you probably do not want to do the same pattern in the next few weeks.
The only one where I've made it so far was the last one where it started off this way...  After a while I'd add a stitch or two and then put it back together in the same place... I don't want to repeat it!  It's only for a couple of days though so I should have a new pattern ready soon...

The first three lines of the pattern are the same as in the second pattern. There's no further repetition of the pattern. The last three lines are the same as in the first pattern without any "no repeat" lines. The idea has been the same.
 Now let's try it for three other patterns:
In: 0 3
Out: 1 0
In: 1 0
Out: 2

Out: 5
In: 0 0
Out: 1 0

In:      4 0 0
Out: 4 1 0
The first two lines are the same as in the pattern first pattern:
In: 0 2
Out: 2 3 0
The second two lines are the same as the pattern first pattern:
(The first two lines of the pattern are identical.)
Then the third line of the pattern is:
In: 6 2
Out: 3 5 0
The third line of the pattern is the same as the pattern first pattern:
In: 0 4
Out: 3 3 0
The fifth line of the pattern is identical to the pattern first pattern:
 In: 0 3
Out: 1 3 0 0 
The fifth, or last line of the pattern, is the same as the pattern first pattern: 1 
Now you see why this is.
 The pattern is actually three repeats of one pattern with "no repeat" lines interspersed. This pattern is similar to our first sequence of patterns in how it repeats itself in three patterns. 
That's it for my introductory lesson on patterns and patterns in general. If you have any questions about the "no repeat" lines please leave a comment below or ask me directly over on the Ask Dr. Pattern page (I'm probably around all of you). Also feel free to bookmark or share this page with other people who are learning patterns in general.

I've finally finished the pattern you see above - which is easy to do, because I keep using the same stitches over and over again. It should be easier than the rest of your pattern for the beginner, and should feel quite familiar at this point.
Now that we can play with the stitches in this pattern, and use them like we would with any other pattern stitch, let's make a couple of small changes.
Seed to End, Row 1:  You will have to know the difference between "seed to end", and "one stitch out" in order to tell which method is being used here. Basically, seed is a row that you work in a repeating pattern, and end, as seen below in Row 1.
If you want to use this as an example, you will only need to start the pattern in the pattern of seed stitches across the upper side of the quilt from  Row 1 of your chart. As seen in the last image above, I have finished the pattern with one stitch out, which is a row which repeats until you have finished the whole work.
Row 1: In: 0 2, 2 2, 0 2, 2 2; In: 0 4, 4 0, 0 2, 2 2; In: 0 4, 4 0, 0 3, 3 0; In: 0 4, 4 0, 1, 1 0; In: 0 4, 4 0, 2, 3 0; In: 0 4, 4 0, 2, 4 0; In: 0 4, 4 0, 0, 5 0; In: 0 4, 4 0, 0, 1 0; In: 0 4, 4 0, 0, 2 0
